title: Domain 4.2: Summarize various types of attacks and their impact to the network.
content:
🚫 Denial-of-Service (DoS)/Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS)

Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks aim to make a network or service unavailable by overwhelming it with traffic or exploiting vulnerabilities.

Common use: Overloading a website’s server with traffic to make it crash.

Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks involve multiple systems working together to launch a coordinated attack, making it harder to defend against.

Common use: Botnets are often used in DDoS attacks to flood a target network with massive traffic.

🌐 VLAN Hopping

VLAN Hopping allows attackers to send traffic between VLANs (Virtual Local Area Networks) that should be isolated from each other. This is typically done by exploiting misconfigurations.

Common use: Exploiting a switch’s vulnerability to bridge traffic from one VLAN to another, gaining access to sensitive data.

🏷️ MAC Flooding

MAC Flooding involves overwhelming a switch with fake MAC addresses, causing it to fail and revert to behaving like a hub. This allows attackers to intercept network traffic.

Common use: To bypass a switch’s security and potentially sniff traffic.

🔍 ARP Poisoning & 👀 ARP Spoofing

ARP Poisoning (or ARP Spoofing) involves sending fake ARP messages to associate the attacker’s MAC address with the IP address of a legitimate device.

Common use: Enables man-in-the-middle attacks or disrupts communication between devices.

🧠 DNS Poisoning & 🔄 DNS Spoofing

DNS Poisoning involves corrupting the DNS cache to redirect traffic intended for a legitimate site to a malicious one.

Common use: Redirecting users to fake websites to collect personal data or spread malware.

DNS Spoofing tricks a DNS server into resolving a domain to the wrong IP address.

Common use: Misleading users to phishing or malicious servers.

🚨 Rogue Devices and Services

🔌 Rogue DHCP Server

Issues unauthorized IP addresses, potentially disrupting network operations or redirecting traffic.

📡 Rogue Access Point (AP)

An unauthorized wireless AP that can allow attackers access to the network.

💻 Evil Twin Attack

A rogue AP mimicking a legitimate network to steal user data or install malware.

🛠️ On-Path Attack

Also known as Man-in-the-Middle (MitM), it involves intercepting communications between two parties without their knowledge.

Common use: Eavesdropping on secure web sessions or redirecting traffic.

🧠 Social Engineering

📧 Phishing

Fraudulent attempts to obtain sensitive information by disguising as a trustworthy entity in emails.

🗑️ Dumpster Diving

Searching through trash to find confidential information.

👀 Shoulder Surfing

Stealing information by watching someone enter sensitive data.

🚪 Tailgating

Following an authorized person into a restricted area without credentials.

🦠 Malware

Malicious software designed to harm, exploit, or otherwise compromise systems. Includes viruses, worms, spyware, ransomware, etc.

Common use: Infecting systems to steal data, disrupt services, or demand ransom.
